A big fan of Nobel Laureate Dr. Sheldon Cooper. As a student, as someone who knew him for more than 12 years both his professional and personal side. I can say this for sure, he is a gem of a person. Dr. Cooper is easily the most brilliant man I've ever met. While this has definitely gotten into his head, he loves his subject and understands it on a level that few others do. He's very clear in his expectations, and won't abandon you since he can't just drive away. He also taught me how to play bongos and some Tuvan throat singing!

Knows his stuff, no doubt about that, but is easily sidetracked . For example, Dr. Cooper launched into a lengthy discussion about flags during one class which was supposed to be about string theory. Huh? And don't even get him started about Will Wheaton or engineers. He'll go off on a tirade and then assign extra homework just to vent his spleen.
The subject is very tough, but he is an awesome guy and he tells crazy stories about his Mother in Texas .

Lectures are long! Homework is very difficult, but you will learn. Take this class seriously and you'll pass. Not recommended unless you're pursuing a PhD in Physics. On a higher note, he's really cute so you'll have something to look at while he rambles on during lectures.
Dr. Cooper is knows his stuff, no doubt, but the TA Amy Fowler grades unbelievably harsh! No partial credit at all on exams, especially if you make a simple multiplication mistake like my friend.

Dr. Farrah Fowler is a great neurobiologist and teaches phenomenally well. She is a Nobel Laureate. She is eccentric, but she deals with her husband on a daily basis and grew up with her parents, so it's hard to get on her bad side. Her expectations are firm but predictable. Her wealth of knowledge of neurobiology makes the class well worth taking.

DON'T TAKE THIS CLASS!  If you are not a Geo major take Ge1 without a doubt.  If you might be a Geo major (slacker!) take anything other than this class.  I've heard good things about Ay1.

Not many people can talk for three hours and still keep me awake, but Manning was one of them.  He spoke with great clarity and made Kant's ideas almost straightforward.  He is a hard grader (and said so on the first day of class), so I think most people took his class pass fail.

Professor Mantovan gave a helpful and clear introduction to linear algebra. I didn't pick up on all points the first time around, but she was open to taking student's questions and chose examples that demonstrated the material well. Overall Prof. Mantovan did a good job of giving students a practically focused introduction to matrix algebra.

Intense and brilliant man also very entertaining especially when he starts ranting. Text book was only assigned so he could mock the mistakes. Be prepared to be insulted, a lot.  He is geeky hot (nice shoulders) and has an incredibly hot boyfriend, so you are occasionally treated to some extra eye candy when he stops by at the end of class.

So, I'm not even sure how I got in that class cause I was majoring in animal sciences, but wow, that mans voice. It was my favorite nap time of the day listening to him talk (and yell) for an hour a day. 10/10 would recommend.
Overall he did a good job when I took his class (except when he was trying to explain the Meredith connection, and then he kept bragging about some Air Force stuff that wasn't in the syllabus...)
I don't know how he gets off teaching these classes. His sarcasm in the extragalactic seminar is uncalled for. But I respect his brilliance.
Rodney's car has horrible suspension and automatic transmission.

Alright, so maybe I was a little distracted in his classes... but really, a lot of his stuff goes way over everyone's heads, though you can tell he's a genius. Will probably give you the tongue lashing of your life if you're late - says textbooks are "moronic and written for babies". His hot boyfriend comes around a lot too! Worth it!

He's either way over my head or he dumbs it down so much that I've come close to hitting him several times. Having the text book nearby would be too much of a temptation to throw it at his head. Despite this, you can't argue with his results. Much.
I adored this class.  He was hard but I learned a lot.
Whoa. Absolutely brilliant and horribly abrasive, but totally worth it. But then, I am a masochist anyway.

Very hard class but worth it. McKay is loud and abrasive but also scary smart and GEEKY-HOT. He's demanding and expects you to actually think. You will learn...not to ask stupid questions

TERRIFYING. Also, this is supposed to be a 101 class. Kept going on about wormholes? WHAT? Brilliant, but really, intensely frightening & I ended up dropping. That said I still don't know what 90% of the words coming out of his mouth were, but I have the funny impression that they were important.
He is brilliant but terrifying!!  I never missed a class! Hardest class I've ever taken.
Only assigned textbooks to lecture about what was wrong about them.

This guys.. pretty weird. He talks on about wormholes and gatestars like they actually exist which was kinda odd. Pretty hot though.
I Will NEVER ENJOY Astrophysics AGAIN and i'm switching my major to ENGLISH! Take that RODNEY MCKAY!!!!!

Spent a lot of time talking about wormhole physics and deep space telemetry which is awesome, except the class was supposed to be "Intro to Astronomy for Non Science Majors". I just pretended he was talking about Star Trek.

Most traumatic academic experience of my life. If it weren't a 300-Level class, I'd swear it was a freshmen-weeder.  Only reason I passed was the TA, who handled all of Dr. McKay's office hours and could double as a shrink.  Talk to the TA before taking one of McKay's classes, but you'll definitely learn from the experience.
Physics was my world. Now my shrink's office is my refuge.
He's more interested in proving how smart he is than actually teaching.  Only take this class if you absolutely must.

Took an upper level philosophy class from him that was fascinating. He was clealry frustrated by the lack of class participation (in a six person class) and seemed mean as a result. However, he really knows his stuff and is actually helpful if you are willing to put in the effort.
